Smith|A.H.Sm.]] (1976) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Boletus barrowsii'' | whichGills = adnate | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=pores | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=olive | howEdible=choice }} '''''Boletus barrowsii''''', also known in English as the '''white king bolete''' after its pale colored [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], is an [[edible mushrooms|edible]] and highly regarded [[fungus]] in the genus ''[[Boletus]]'' that inhabits southwestern North America. Found under [[ponderosa pine]] and [[live oak]] in autumn, it was considered a color variant of the similarly edible ''[[Boletus edulis|B. edulis]]'' for many years.{{cite book |last=Arora |first=David |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms demystified: a comprehensive guide to the fleshy fungi |edition=2nd |location=Berkeley |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |page=529 |authorlink=David Arora |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Thiers HD, Smith AH |year=1976 |title=Boletes of the Southwestern United States |journal=Mycotaxon |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=261–73 |url=http://194.203.77.76/LibriFungorum/Image.asp?ItemID=85&ImageFileName=0261b.jpg }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Taxonomy and naming== It was officially described by American mycologists [[Harry D. Thiers]] and [[Alexander H. Smith]] in 1976 from a specimen collected near [[Jacob Lake, Arizona]] on August 21, 1971 by amateur mycologist Charles "Chuck" Barrows, who had studied the mushroom in New Mexico. It was previously held to be a white colour form of ''[[Boletus edulis]]''. A 2010 molecular study found that ''B. barrowsii'' was sister to a lineage that gave rise to the species ''[[Boletus quercophilus|B. quercophilus]]'' of Costa Rica and ''[[Boletus nobilissimus|B. nobilissimus]]'' of eastern North America.{{cite journal |vauthors=Dentinger BT, Ammirati JF, Both EE, Desjardin DE, Halling RE, Henkel TW, Moreau PA, Nagasawa E, Soytong K, Taylor AF, Watling R, Moncalvo JM, McLaughlin DJ |title=Molecular phylogenetics of porcini mushrooms (''Boletus'' section ''Boletus'') |journal=Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume=57 |year=2010 |pages=1276–92 |url=http://static.msi.umn.edu/rreports/2010/211.pdf |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2010.10.004 |pmid=20970511 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523094609/http://static.msi.umn.edu/rreports/2010/211.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-23 }} ''Boletus barrowsii'' could possibly be confused with the similarly pale-capped ''[[Boletus satanas]]'', though the [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] of the latter stains blue when cut or bruised, and it has a reddish stem and pores. The latter species is [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] when raw. ==Description== The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is 6–25 cm (2–10 in) in diameter, initially convex in shape before flattening, with a smooth or slightly tomentose surface, and gray-white, white or [[buff (color)|buff]] colour. The thick flesh is white and does not turn blue when bruised. The pores are initially whitish, later yellow. The [[spore print]] is olive brown, the [[basidiospore|spores]] are elliptical to spindle-shaped and 13–15 x 4–5 [[micrometre|μm]] in dimensions. The stout [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is white with a brown reticulated pattern, and may be 6–20 cm (2½–8 in) high with an apical diameter of 2–6 cm (1–2 in). Like ''B. edulis'', it is often found eaten by [[maggot]]s. ==Distribution and habitat== The white king bolete is [[ectomycorrhiza]]l, found under [[ponderosa pine]] (''Pinus ponderosa'') inland, and [[coast live oak]] (''Quercus agrifolia'') closer to the west coast. Fruit bodies appear after rain, and will be more abundant if this occurs in early autumn rather than later in the year through to winter. It is abundant in the warmer parts of its range, namely [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]], but also occurs in [[Colorado]] and west into [[California]]. It has been recorded from the San Marcos Foothills in [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara County]].{{cite web | vauthors = Holmgren M, Stone T, Kelly M | url = http://www.sanmarcosfoothills.org/Plan4/PDF/SMFC_Plan.pdf | title = A Plan for the Preservation and Stewardship of San Marcos Foothills Coalition, Santa Barbara, California | year = 2001 | pages = 1–94 | location = Santa Barbara | publisher = San Marcos Foothills Coalition | format = PDF | accessdate = 2008-03-12 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080513214513/http://sanmarcosfoothills.org/Plan4/PDF/SMFC_Plan.pdf | archivedate = 2008-05-13 }} ==Edibility== It is [[edible mushroom|edible]] and highly regarded in New Mexico, Arizona, and Colorado, and was eaten for many years while assumed to be a form of ''B. edulis''. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of Boletus species|List of ''Boletus'' species]] *[[List of North American boletes]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1102113}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boletus Barrowsii}} [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Boletus|barrowsii]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1976]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Taxa named by Harry Delbert Thiers]] [[Category:Taxa named by Alexander H.
